critique: This executive order temporarily suspends the eight-hour law for laborers and mechanics employed by the Department of the Army or the Department of the Air Force under specific conditions (supply/maintenance of forces, essential construction, international commitments). It extends a previous order due to an ongoing emergency. The wages are still computed on an eight-hour day with overtime pay. This seems to be a temporary measure during an emergency (likely post-WWII). It is difficult to assess a strong ideological tilt. It does involve economic regulation by suspending a labor law, but it also maintains overtime pay. It doesn't directly address immigration, executive power significantly, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. Given the context of a post-war emergency, a moderate intervention is justifiable.
